questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender XDR and contains two users named User1 and User2.

You need to ensure that the users can perform searches by using the Microsoft Purview portal. The solution must meet the following requirements:

• Ensure that User1 can search the Microsoft Purview Audit service logs and review the Microsoft Purview Audit service configuration.
• Ensure that User2 can search Microsoft Exchange Online mailboxes.
• Follow the principle of least privilege.

To which Microsoft Purview role group should you add each user? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
User1: Microsoft Purview Audit Reader
User2: Microsoft Purview Data Investigator
Answer is correct

User1: Audit Reader
Search audit logs and review audit config with minimal permissions.
User2: Data Investigator
Search Exchange mailboxes with investigation-focused access, adhering to least privilege as closely as possible.

Security Reader: A user that belongs to this role has read-only access to Defender for Cloud. The user can view recommendations, alerts, a security policy, and security states, but can't make changes.

comments.content:
actually audit reader has that same permission
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/purview/audit-get-started

discussion.content:
User 1: Global Reader
User 2: Data Investigator

It's Global Reader, not Audit Reader. The Audit Reader role lacks the permissions to view configuration. The Global Reader has this ability while also being able to search audit logs (see table in the link, Global Reader has "View-only Audit Logs" permission)

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Endpoint Plan 2 and contains 500 Windows devices.

As part of an incident investigation, you identify the following suspected malware files:

• sys
• pdf
• docx
• xlsx

You need to create indicator hashes to block users from downloading the files to the devices.

Which files can you block by using the indicator hashes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Based on File hashes, you should be able to block each and every file with this hash, regardless the name of the file.

comments.content: I second this...adding though that M$ doesn't recommend using hash based IOC since they can change in a blink of an eye but use App control instead (side note), so Answer E, undoubtedly since a hash is file name and extension agnostic.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Key Points:

 Executable Files: Microsoft Defender for Endpoint can block executable files such as .exe, .dll, .sys, and other similar types.
 Non-Executable Files: Generally, Microsoft Defender for Endpoint does not allow blocking of non-executable files (e.g., .pdf, .docx, .xlsx) by file hash using the same indicator mechanism designed for executables.

Selected Answer: E
You make get a hash for every file and block it.

Selected Answer: E
I am gonna go with a whim and select E for one reason, I remember blocking all types of files including pdfs we block with hashes I think

Selected Answer: E
Question is about hashes. You can add any hash to Defender and it will be blocked.

Selected Answer: A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/indicator-file
From Microsoft:
"File indicators support portable executable (PE) files, including .exe and .dll files only."

Only the .sys is a PE file, therefore it is the only file that can be blocked via file indicator.

Selected Answer: A
File indicators only support Portable Execution (PE) files like exe, dll, sys
File indicators only support Portable Execution (PE) files like exe, dll, sys
Answer is D: Blocking .sys files could affect system functionality, and thus Defender for Endpoint does not allow blocking system-critical files.

E
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/indicator-file

Selected Answer: E
I took the hash from (.pdf, sys, doc,) and each file and was able to upload successfully. Therefore, the answer is E.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
This feature is designed to prevent suspected malware (or potentially malicious files) from being downloaded from the web. It currently supports portable executable (PE) files, including .exe and .dll files.

Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/indicator-file

Answer - C (.sys , .docx, .xlsx
 as per this explanation by Copilot - You can create indicator hashes to block executable files with the following extensions: .exe, .dll, and .sys. Additionally, Office files like .docx and .xlsx can also be blocked using indicator hashes. However, PDF files cannot be blocked using indicator hashes in Microsoft Defender for Endpoint1.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription that uses Microsoft Defender for Endpoint and contains a user named User1 and a Microsoft 365 group named Group1. All users are assigned a Defender for Endpoint Plan 1 license.

You enable Microsoft Defender XDR Unified role-based access control (RBAC) for Endpoints & Vulnerability Management.

You need to ensure that User1 can configure alerts that will send email notifications to Group1. The solution must follow the principle of least privilege.

Which permissions should you assign to User1?

comments.content:
The link support the answer to be D.
"Only users with 'Manage security settings' permissions can configure email notifications."

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
You can configure Microsoft Defender XDR to send email notifications to specified recipients for new alerts. This feature enables you to identify a group of individuals who will immediately be informed and can act on alerts based on their severity.

If you're using Defender for Business, you can set up email notifications for specific users (not roles or groups).

 Note

Only users with 'Manage security settings' permissions can configure email notifications. If you've chosen to use basic permissions management, users with Security Administrator or Global Administrator roles can configure email notifications.
Device group creation is supported in Defender for Endpoint Plan 1 and Plan 2.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-xdr/configure-email-notifications
Answer is for sure D based on https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-endpoint/user-roles

Selected Answer: B
It's B
Manage Alerts can be done by the following Roles:
Security operations \ Security data \ Security data basics (read)
Security operations \ Security data \ Alerts (manage)

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-xdr/compare-rbac-roles
